instance.advanced.security.title: Security
instance.advanced.security.certificate.title: SSL Certificate Applied
instance.advanced.security.certificate.subtitle: If enabled, SSL certificate will be applied to this domain.
instance.advanced.security.certificate.label: Certificate:
instance.advanced.security.forceRedirect.title: Force HTTPS Redirect
instance.advanced.security.forceRedirect.subtitle: If enabled, http:// requests will be redirected to https:// on this domain.
instance.advanced.security.modal.forceRedirect.in: This instance is installed on {{domain}} along with other instances. Changing this option, it will also affect the following instances:
instance.advanced.security.disableSearchEngineInd: If enabled, search engines will be discouraged from indexing this domain.
instance.advanced.autoUpdates.title: Auto Updates
instance.advanced.autoUpdates.upgrade.title: Auto Upgrade
instance.advanced.autoUpdates.upgrade.subtitle: If enabled, WordPress will be automatically updated when a new version is available.
instance.advanced.autoUpdates.upgrade.option.late: Update to any latest version available (Major as well as Minor)
instance.advanced.autoUpdates.upgrade.plugin.subt: If enabled, plugins will be automatically updated when a new version is available.
instance.advanced.autoUpdates.upgrade.theme.title: Auto Upgrade Themes
instance.advanced.autoUpdates.upgrade.theme.subti: If enabled, themes will be automatically updated to the latest version when available.
instance.advanced.cloudflare.title: Cloudflare
instance.advanced.cloudflare.manage.title: Manage DNS through Cloudflare
instance.advanced.cloudflare.manage.subtitle: Your site uses Cloudflare DNS for increased security. It provides multiple security layers and protects against DDOS attacks, SQL injection, cross-site scripting, malicious traffic and more.
instance.advanced.cloudflare.manage.label: Status:
instance.advanced.cloudflare.cache.title: Purge Cache
instance.advanced.cloudflare.cache.subtitle: Clear cached files to force Cloudflare to fetch a fresh version of those files from your web server.
instance.advanced.cloudflare.cache.alert: Purging the cache may temporarily degrade performance for your website and increase load on your origin.
instance.advanced.cloudflare.development.title: Development Mode
instance.advanced.cloudflare.development.subtitle: Temporarily bypass our cache allowing you to see changes to your origin server in real time.
instance.advanced.cloudflare.development.alert: Enabling this feature can significantly increase origin sever load. Development mode does not purge the cache so files will need to be purged after development mode expires.
instance.advanced.cloudflare.browser.title: Browser Integrity Check
instance.advanced.cloudflare.browser.subtitle: Evaluate HTTP headers from your visitors browser for threats. If a threat is found a block page will be delivered.
instance.advanced.cloudflare.security.title: Security Level
instance.advanced.cloudflare.security.subtitle: Adjust your website's Security Level to determine which visitors will receive a challenge page.
instance.advanced.cloudflare.modal.purge.title: Confirm purge everything
instance.advanced.cloudflare.modal.purge.info: Purge all cached files. Purging your cache may slow your website temporarily.
instance.advanced.edge-cache.title: Edge Cache
instance.advanced.edge-cache.manage.title: Enable Edge Cache
instance.advanced.edge-cache.manage.subtitle: Edge Cache provides performance improvements, particularly to the Time to First Byte (TTFB), by serving page cache directly from the closest server available to a site's visitors.
instance.advanced.edge-cache.purge.title: Purge
instance.advanced.edge-cache.purge.subtitle: Edge Cache is automatically cleared when the site's content is updated. You may clear site cache manually.
instance.advanced.edge-cache.purge.alert: Clearing your site's cache manually can lead to degraded performance and slower loading times for you and your visitors while the cache is rebuilt. To avoid a performance drop, the server-side cache should be only cleared in rare circumstances.
instance.advanced.edge-cache.defensive-mode.title: Defensive Mode
instance.advanced.edge-cache.defensive-mode.subti: Edge Cache's Defensive Mode provides additional on-demand protection. Defensive mode issues a challenge to browsers visiting the site, mitigating spam bot and DDoS attack requests. Legitimate users will briefly see a challenge page while their browser completes the work before accessing the site.
instance.advanced.edge-cache.modal.purge.title: Confirm Purge Edge Cache
instance.advanced.edge-cache.modal.purge.info: Purge all cache. Purging your cache may slow your website temporarily.
instance.advanced.edge-cache.modal.defensive-mode: Are you sure to enable Defensive Mode for {{value}}?

instance.advanced.developer.debug.title: Debug Mode
instance.advanced.developer.debug.subtitle: Enable WP_DEBUG to display application errors when browsing the site.

phpSetting.allow_url_fopen: This option enables the URL-aware fopen wrappers that enable accessing URL objects like files. Default wrappers are provided for the access of remote files using the ftp or http protocol; some extensions like zlib may register additional wrappers.
phpSetting.display_errors: This determines whether errors should be printed to the screen as part of the output or if they should be hidden from the user.
phpSetting.enable_dl: This directive is really only useful in the Apache module version of PHP. You can turn dynamic loading of PHP extensions with dl() on and off per virtual server or per directory. The main reason for turning dynamic loading off is security. With dynamic loading, it is possible to ignore all open_basedir restrictions. The default is to allow dynamic loading, except when using safe mode. This feature is deprecated and will be removed at a future time.
phpSetting.file_uploads: Whether or not to allow HTTP file uploads.
phpSetting.max_execution_time: This sets the maximum time in seconds a script is allowed to run before it is terminated by the parser. This helps prevent poorly written scripts from tying up the server.
phpSetting.max_input_time: This sets the maximum time in seconds a script is allowed to parse input data, like POST, GET, and file uploads.
phpSetting.max_input_vars: This sets the maximum number of input variables allowed per request and can be used to deter denial of service attacks involving hash collisions on the input variable names.
phpSetting.memory_limit: This sets the maximum amount of memory in bytes that a script is allowed to allocate. This helps prevent poorly written scripts from consuming all available memory on a server. Note that to have no memory limit, set this directive to -1.
phpSetting.post_max_size: Sets the maximum size of post data allowed. This setting also affects file uploads. To upload large files, this value must be larger than upload_max_filesize. Generally speaking, memory_limit should be larger than post_max_size.
phpSetting.session.gc_maxlifetime: This specifies the number of seconds after which data will be seen as 'garbage' and potentially cleaned up.
phpSetting.session.save_path: session.save_path defines the argument which is passed to the save handler. If you choose the default files handler, this is the path where the files are created.
phpSetting.upload_max_filesize: The maximum size of an uploaded file.
phpSetting.zlib.output_compression: Whether to transparently compress pages. If this option is set to 'On' in php.ini or the Apache configuration, pages are compressed if the browser sends an 'Accept-Encoding: gzip' or 'deflate' header.
phpSetting.error_reporting: This setting determines which PHP errors are reported. It can be set to a specific level of error reporting, such as E_ALL, which reports all errors, or it can be set to 0 to disable error reporting.
phpSetting.log_errors: This directive enables or disables the logging of errors to a specified file. When enabled, errors are logged instead of being displayed on the screen, which is useful for production environments.
phpSetting.max_file_uploads: This sets the maximum number of files that can be uploaded via a single request. This helps prevent abuse by limiting the number of files that can be uploaded at once.
phpSetting.register_globals: This directive, when enabled, automatically imports variables from the request into the global scope. It is deprecated and should be disabled for security reasons, as it can lead to variable overwriting and other security issues.
phpSetting.short_open_tag: This setting allows the use of short opening tags (<?) for PHP code. If disabled, only the full opening tag (<?php) can be used. It is recommended to use the full opening tag for better compatibility.
